text: no congress in 224 years of american
history has allowed our country to
default and it's my sincere hope that
this congress will not be the first
there's been a ton of talk about what
will happen if the united states hits
the debt ceiling so what is the debt
ceiling the debt ceiling is a limit on
how much the government can borrow
congress has the power of the purse it
tells the executive branch how much to
spend and how much it can expect to
receive in taxes when treasury faces a
deficit it sells bonds to make up the
difference
the debt ceiling is a cap set by
congress on the value of those bonds
right now we are close to hitting the
debt ceiling which means the treasury
department could lose the ability to pay
the nation's bills if we don't raise the
debt ceiling we're dead beats here's the
math that has economists worried the
treasury would likely miss about 30
percent of the payments it makes daily
payments to state governments social
security recipients bondholders and more
that's bad enough but what has people
really worried is the effect on world
markets if treasury begins to miss
payments it's what is called a sovereign
default it would mean massive disruption
the world over and we would be at risk
of tipping yet again
into recession
world markets will be watching closely
even the threat of a sovereign default
could mean worldwide crisis
investors who have traditionally thought
of the united states as a safe harbor
could panic
some analysts fear that a sovereign
default might well be worse than when
lehman brothers collapsed in 2008.
stocks all around the world are tanking
it's an historic day with wall street
shaken to its very foundation today now
treasury could in theory prioritize
payments to bondholders but that means
stiffing federal workers and local
governments and might not even be legal
it's all uncharted waters
so what does this mean for the average
american before you go out and buy
cartons of cigarettes and prepare for a
barter economy consider that congress
has not allowed the treasury to default
in more than 200 years
investors have gotten used to the idea
that congress waits until the last
minute to solve this problem which is
why investors are not panicking at least
yet
